message_1:
Find the solution of the following system of linear equations:

2x + 3y = 13
4x - 5y = -2
message_2:
To solve this system of linear equations, we can use the method of substitution or elimination. Here, we will use the elimination method.

First, we need to make the coefficients of either x or y the same in both equations. In this case, we can multiply the first equation by 2 to make the coefficients of x the same:

(2)(2x + 3y) = (2)(13)
4x + 6y = 26

Now we have the following system of equations:

4x + 6y = 26
4x - 5y = -2

Next, subtract the second equation from the first equation to eliminate the x variable:

(4x + 6y) - (4x - 5y) = 26 - (-2)
4x + 6y - 4x + 5y = 28
11y = 28

Now, divide by 11 to solve for y:

y = 28 / 11

Now that we have the value of y, we can substitute it back into one of the original equations to solve for x. We'll use the first equation:

2x + 3y = 13
2x + 3(28/11) = 13

Multiply both sides by 11 to get rid of the fraction:

11(2x) + 11(3)(28/11) = 13(11)
22x + 84 = 143

Now, subtract 84 from both sides:

22x = 59

Finally, divide by 22 to solve for x:

x = 59 / 22

So, the solution to the system of linear equations is:

x = 59/22
y = 28/11
